dc:description:
*TRAC* was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive TCR-alpha-beta-positive T-cell deficiency in 2011 (Morgan NV, et al., 2011, PMID: 21206088 ). The *TRAC* gene encodes for the constant region of the TCR subunit and is essential for membrane expression of the αβTCR heterodimer, which recognizes a complex consisting of an antigen-derived peptide bound to a class I or class II MHC protein. *TRAC* deficiency is characterized by onset of recurrent bacterial and viral infections in infancy or early childhood. Evidence supporting the gene-disease relationship includes 3 probands plus 2 additional affected family members, all with the same homozygous c. *1G > A variant, reported in 2 publications (PMIDs: 21206088, 33909184). An additional patient, with homozygous Ser116Ter, was reported in doi.org/10.14785/lymphosign-2022-0001 (Garkaby et al., 2022). Heterozygous parents were reported to be clinically unaffected in all families. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by experimental evidence, including its function in the TCR (PMID: 2421164) which is altered in patient cells (PMID: 33909184). As well as expression that is enriched in lymphoid tissues and specifically enhanced in T-cells but altered in patient cells (PMID: 21206088). In summary, there is moderate evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship.

This classification was originally approved by the ClinGen SCID-CID GCEP on August 18, 2022. This genedisease relationship was re-evaluated on July 17, 2025. As a result of this re-evaluation, no new evidence was indentified and the classification did not change.
curationReasonDescription: An additional patient whose immune evaluation revealed profound lymphopenia, depressed responses to the mitogen PHA and a skewed T cell repertoire, was homozygous for Ser116Ter, was reported in doi.org/10.14785/lymphosign-2022-0001 (Garkaby et al., 2022) and was scored 2pt but does not have a PMID so could not be entered in the GCI. The additional 2pt increases the point total to 8pt and a Moderate classification.

evidence.previousTestingDescription:
Flow cytometry reveled conventional CD3+ T cells were present but uniformly expressed TCRγδ, with or without CD8, and an abnormal population of CD3lo cells expressing TCRαβ at extremely low levels.

Despite these profound T cell abnormalities, class-switched memory B cells were present, immunoglobulin levels were within the normal range, and vaccine responses were demonstrable.

evidence.dc:description: In the predicted translation product, the 35 C-terminal amino acids are replaced by 56 amino acids encoded by exon 4 (p.Thr107LeufsX56). This results in partial loss of the connecting peptide domain and abolition of the transmembrane and cytoplasmic domains of the TCRα chain. Previously, deletion of as few as 9 amino acids from the C-terminus of the TCRα chain has been reported to impair assembly and/or intracellular transport of TCR-CD3 complexes (PMID: 11566319, PMID: 12695121). Additionally a conserved motif (FETDxNLN), present in the α chain connecting peptide domain, was shown to be critical in controlling antigen responsiveness (PMID: 8934571). Therefore, the c.*1G>A mutation–associated splicing defect would be expected to have a profound impact on TCRα chain structure and function.

The c.*1G>A substitution occurs at the last nucleotide of exon 3 (immediately following the translation termination codon). RT-PCR analysis of TRAC cDNA revealed exon skipping of the last coding exon (exon 3), resulting in an aberrant transcript joining exon 2 to the normally untranslated exon 4.

Consistent with its role in the T-cell receptor, The Human Protein Atlas reports that expression of TRAC is enriched in lymphoid tissues and specifically enhanced in T-cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: T-cell expression

evidence.dc:description:
When assessed by flow cytometry, surface staining for TCRαβ was strongly reduced in patient cells. Additionally, patient cells showed undetectably low expression of either TCRα or TCRβ polypeptides by immunoblotting.

Furthermore, PBMCs were immunostained with antibodies against T cell receptor α and β chains. In control cells, colocalization of α and β chains within distinct areas of the cell membrane was readily apparent. Patient cells showed reduced levels of expression and no evidence of colocalization, suggesting that the mutant α chain fails to complex normally with the TCR β chain. Consistent with this and in contrast to wild-type TCRα, mutant HA-tagged TCRα, and GFP-tagged TCRβ failed to colocalize intracellularly in transfected HeLa cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: Reduced TCRα and TCRβ expression

evidence.dc:description:
Here they showed that T-cell receptor α- and β-chain genes, isolated from a cytotoxic T cell, are sufficient to transfer that cell's MHC restricted antigen specificity to another T cell.

The cytotoxic T-cell clone BDFL, isolated from mice shows specificity for the hapten fluorescein (FL) and the MHC class I antigen D. The BDFL genes were transferred, by cosmid, into SPH recipient T cells, and conferred specificity for FL-coupled L-Dd.

The authors addressed the question of  whether the α- and β-chains are sufficient to endow a T cell with both antigen and MHC specificity  by gene transfer between T cells of different specificities.

Since the TRAC gene encodes for the constant region of the TCR subunit and is essential for membrane expression of the αβTCR heterodimer, it follows that disruption of this gene would lead to immunodeficiency.
evidence.rdfs:label: αβTCR specificity

evidence.dc:description: Demonstrated that TRAC deficiency is characterized by increased usage of 5′ TRAV and 3′ TRAJ gene segments. The authors postulate that the inability of TRAC-mutated patients to express a functional, membrane-bound TCRαβ heterodimer allowing positive selection may induce developing thymocytes to continue to rearrange the TRA locus until the distal TRAV and TRAJ segments are selected for rearrangement, and yet no functional TCRα protein is expressed on the membrane.

To assess the impact of the TRAC gene variant on T cell receptor repertoire, the authors performed high-throughput sequencing of DNA rearrangements at the TCRα (TRA) and TCRβ (TRB) loci in all 3 patients, using peripheral blood genomic DNA as template. TRB rearrangements are polyclonal, with preserved usage of TRBV and TRBJ genes. However, analysis of TRA rearrangements reveals preferential usage of the most upstream (5′) TRAV and the most downstream (3′) TRAJ gene segments.
evidence.rdfs:label: TCR Repertoire Analysis
